text:
I wanted to know how a particular thing that involved wrapping a C-library was done.
So I was like _“I will take a glance at the python library that wraps that C library. See how they do it”_
But no.
The “python” wrapper, is itself implemented about 50% in C.
Because of course it is.

elements.text:
I wanted to know how a particular thing that involved wrapping a C-library was done.
So I was like
“I will take a glance at the python library that wraps that C library. See how they do it”

But no.
The “python” wrapper, is itself implemented about 50% in C.

text: I mean isn't python just C?

elements.text: I mean isn't python just C?

text: <@U6A936746> I'm not sure what to think of that...  You will either really really love or really really hate the package I'm working on...

elements.text: I'm not sure what to think of that...  You will either really really love or really really hate the package I'm working on...

text:
The thing that's extra not great is this is probably less friendly C code than the original.
Since it has to do all kind of PyObject stuff.
I thought CPython was good at calling C.
So even if another wrapper layer was needed it would still be able to be agnostic to the fact that it was being used by python.
I guess not when it comes to dealing with nontrivial python types.

text: <@U6A936746> would you mind telling us what package this is?  I would like to shame my python colleagues with it :laughing:
